fields.description:
As a cloud user I would like to be able to assume a role using my (oidc) web identity so that I can more easily make use of cloud resources.

This story requires support for iam oidc provider configuration. This story does not cover other types of web identity provider.

This story includes development of tests that cover the main use case and any important negative test cases.

comments.body:
I'm running into an problem and not sure how to work around it, within the confines of the API. To configure an openid connect provider, we must provide the url, client id and thumbprint. The url and client id are used on the console as well. The thumbprint is a hash of the server certificate (described more here http://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/APIReference/API_CreateOpenIDConnectProvider.html).
To verify the token a user provides with AssumeRoleWithWebIdentity, we'd make a call to the token/introspect API of the provider and need to provide BASIC auth using the client id and secret. We use the secret on the console to handle this auth, but there is no way, via the API) to provide this secret, or the basic auth string resulting from combining the client id and secret.
We could add the secret to our config file and let each user add the openid connect provider (and role for that) on a per-account basis.
I don't think I'm missing anything, but wanted to talk about options.
[~sjones]

I could see having a config for oidc providers the cloud supports. I thought amazon only supports certain providers. If that were true, they wouldn't need the thumbprint supplied.
I find this on their site, so I guess they support them generically.
"Instead, users of your app can sign in using a well-known identity provider (IdP) —such as Login with Amazon, Facebook, Google, or any other OpenID Connect (OIDC)-compatible IdP..."

I've looked in the jwt returned by globus and found:
{code}
>> parts = jwt.split('.')
>>> print json.dumps(json.loads(base64.b64decode(parts[0])), indent=2)
{
  "alg": "RS512", 
  "typ": "JWT"
}
>>> print json.dumps(json.loads(base64.b64decode(parts[1])), indent=2)
{
  "nonce": null, 
  "aud": "659067ec-9698-44a8-88ea-db31e071447a", 
  "iss": "https://auth.globus.org", 
  "preferred_username": "dkavanagh@gmail.com", 
  "name": "David Kavanagh", 
  "at_hash": "CKS-XakJWAgW7gI1gkhR-l7GYWBAGBJiJH42lE5VMiE=", 
  "exp": 1466355348, 
  "iat": 1466182548, 
  "email": "dkavanagh@gmail.com", 
  "sub": "6f3a17d4-538e-4431-889b-f61aea15cf0c"
}
{code}

1st part is the header, then content, with the last part being the signature (not json).

The "aud" matches the oidc provider clientId. "iss" matches the oidc provider url.

[~sjones]
I've thrown together some code that proves out steps 2-5 from this document: https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/~sjones/OIDC+Assume+Role+Notes
[~sjones], need a hand or pointer to policy verification. I'm going to do the spike where I test globus and tooling against AWS, but will be back to Euca soon.

[~dkavanagh], I haven't looked into the design for policy evaluation yet. I think it is a bit different than the typical case due to differences in the way the principal must be handled. I'll take a look at how this could work and update the design document as soon as possible (next few days)

[~dkavanagh], I haven't had time to write this up yet, but here is an attempt at supporting contextual attributes for policy evaluation:

  https://github.com/sjones4/eucalyptus/commit/5cab88d7836e507d7d4b27449c063b0784c51010

The change for TokensService#assumeRole external ID shows how this would be used. To set a principal you would use the keys such as RestrictedTypes#principalTypeContextKey.

For the condition, I think we'd need something like dynamic/contextual condition key support which I have not looked at yet.

[~dkavanagh], an attempt at dynamic condition key support:

  https://github.com/sjones4/eucalyptus/commit/89bfc24973862f18eb4191e076fb733f5e91d9c8

This adds an OpenIDConnectAudKey condition key with a value that can be put in the PolicyEvaluationContext (from the previous commit) as an attribute before policy evaluation.

More thought is needed on how to support dynamic condition keys, but I think this is sufficient for use when assuming a role.

I can see performance reasons. Not so sure about the other use case. If the provider has an outage, they won't get a web token, and so it doesn't matter if we can't reach the provider on the back end.

I was curious about commons-codec vs guava for base64 decode. The result of timing 10k iterations for each shows guava is about twice as fast as commons-codec:

[root@osboxes clc]# java -classpath lib/commons-codec-1.10.jar:lib/guava-18.0.jar:. decodetest
guava decode 0.125 seconds
apache decode 0.273 seconds
[root@osboxes clc]# java -classpath lib/commons-codec-1.10.jar:lib/guava-18.0.jar:. decodetest
guava decode 0.122 seconds
apache decode 0.258 seconds
[root@osboxes clc]# java -classpath lib/commons-codec-1.10.jar:lib/guava-18.0.jar:. decodetest
guava decode 0.123 seconds
apache decode 0.259 seconds

for reference:
aws --endpoint-url http://tokens.mycloud.dak.com:8773/ sts assume-role-with-web-identity --role-arn arn:aws:iam::000680909386:role/assume-role2 --role-session-name dkavanagh@gmail.com --no-sign-request --web-identity-token <token-text>

This story is covered by the following n4j test:

https://github.com/eucalyptus/n4j/pull/13
Not verified by internal QA. No report of not working from the target audience. Supplied automated tests have been verified to have worked.
Moving 4.4.0 Issues from Release Pending to Resolved
